questions.question: What is unique about a cat's retractable claws?
options: They can be replaced if broken
They are made of special bone
questions.explanation: Cat claws retract into a protective sheath, allowing cats to move silently and protect the claws from damage when not in use.

questions.question: Which cat breed originated from Turkey and loves swimming?
questions.explanation: The Turkish Van is known for its unusual love of water and swimming, unlike most cats who avoid water.

questions.question: How can you tell a cat is happy when it approaches you?
questions.explanation: A cat with its tail held straight up is displaying confidence and friendly intentions - it's a classic happy greeting posture.

questions.question: What evolutionary advantage do cats gain from purring?
questions.explanation: Cat purring occurs at a frequency that promotes healing of bones and tissues, helping cats recover faster from injuries.

questions.question: Which feature is unique to the Scottish Fold cat breed?
questions.explanation: Scottish Fold cats have a natural dominant gene mutation that affects cartilage, causing their ears to fold forward and downward.

questions.question: What is the function of a cat's whiskers?
questions.explanation: Cat whiskers are sensitive touch receptors that help cats determine if they can fit through spaces and navigate in darkness.

questions.question: Why do cats knead with their paws?
questions.explanation: Kneading is a behavior that persists from kittenhood when kittens knead their mother's belly to stimulate milk flow. Adult cats often knead when content.

questions.question: Which of these is toxic to cats but not to most other animals?
questions.explanation: Lilies are extremely toxic to cats and can cause kidney failure even in small amounts, while many other animals can tolerate them.

questions.question: What is unique about the vision of cats compared to humans?
questions.explanation: Cats have a reflective layer behind their retina called the tapetum lucidum that enhances their night vision to be about six times better than humans.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a cat's slow blink?
questions.explanation: A cat's slow blink, sometimes called a 'cat kiss', is a sign of trust and affection. When cats slow blink at you, they're showing they feel safe.

questions.question: Which wild cat is the domestic cat most closely related to?
questions.explanation: Domestic cats evolved from the African wildcat (Felis silvestris lybica) and share about 95% of their genetic makeup.

questions.question: What unique ability do calico cats have?
questions.explanation: Unlike most cats who are color-blind, calico cats have been found to have some color vision due to their unique genetic makeup.

questions.question: How do mother cats carry their kittens?
questions.explanation: Mother cats carry kittens by the scruff, which triggers a relaxation response in kittens and makes them go limp for safe transport.

questions.question: What happens to a cat's pupils in bright light?
questions.explanation: In bright light, a cat's pupils contract into vertical slits, allowing precise control of light and better depth perception.

questions.question: Which feature helps cats always land on their feet?
questions.explanation: Cats have a natural 'righting reflex' that allows them to twist their flexible spine mid-air to land on their feet when falling.

questions.question: What is the normal body temperature of a cat?
questions.explanation: A cat's normal body temperature is slightly higher than humans, ranging from 100.5 to 102.5°F (38.1 to 39.2°C).

questions.question: Which cat holds the record for the loudest purr?
questions.explanation: Smokey, a British cat, holds the Guinness World Record for the loudest purr by a domestic cat, reaching 67.8 decibels.

questions.question: What ability do cats lose as they mature?
questions.explanation: Most adult cats become lactose intolerant, losing the ability to digest milk properly as they mature past kittenhood.

questions.question: What is a cat's most popular sleeping position?
questions.explanation: The curled-up position is most popular as it conserves heat and protects vital organs, showing cats still retain wild instincts.

questions.question: Which country has the highest cat ownership per capita?
questions.explanation: New Zealand has the highest rate of cat ownership per capita, with nearly half of households owning at least one cat.

questions.question: Which animal has the largest brain in the world?
questions.explanation: The blue whale has the largest brain of any animal, weighing about 17 pounds (7.8 kg).

questions.question: Which bird can fly backward?
questions.explanation: The hummingbird is the only bird that can fly backward due to its unique wing structure and flight muscles.

questions.question: What is the fastest land animal?
questions.explanation: The cheetah is the fastest land animal, capable of reaching speeds up to 70 mph (113 km/h) in short bursts.

questions.question: Which animal has the longest lifespan?
questions.explanation: The bowhead whale has the longest known lifespan of any mammal, potentially living over 200 years.

questions.question: Which animal never sleeps?
questions.explanation: Giraffes only sleep about 30 minutes per day, in very short intervals, but never enter deep sleep in the wild.

questions.question: Which insect has the best eyesight?
questions.explanation: Dragonflies have compound eyes with up to 30,000 facets, giving them nearly 360-degree vision and the ability to see ultraviolet light.

questions.question: Which animal has the strongest bite force?
questions.explanation: The saltwater crocodile has the strongest measured bite force of any animal, up to 3,700 pounds per square inch (psi).

questions.question: Which animal can regrow its head?
questions.explanation: Some species of flatworms (planarians) can regenerate their entire bodies from small pieces, including growing a new head.

questions.question: Which animal has blue blood?
questions.explanation: Horseshoe crabs have blue blood due to the copper-based molecule hemocyanin, which transports oxygen instead of iron-based hemoglobin.

questions.question: Which animal can change its sex?
questions.explanation: Parrotfish can change their sex from female to male, with some species changing color during the transformation.

questions.question: Which animal has the longest migration?
questions.explanation: The Arctic tern migrates from the Arctic to the Antarctic and back annually, covering about 44,000 miles (71,000 km).

questions.question: Which animal can survive being frozen?
questions.explanation: Wood frogs can survive being frozen solid, with their hearts stopping and ice crystals forming in their blood, thanks to special proteins and glucose.

questions.question: Which animal sleeps the most?
questions.explanation: Brown bats sleep up to 20 hours a day, making them one of the sleepiest animals in the world.

questions.question: Which animal has the best sense of smell?
questions.explanation: African elephants have the best sense of smell among all animals, able to detect water sources from several miles away.

questions.question: Which animal doesn't drink water?
questions.explanation: The kangaroo rat never drinks water, getting all the moisture it needs from the seeds it eats and efficient kidneys.

questions.question: Which bird builds the largest nest?
questions.explanation: The sociable weaver of Africa builds massive communal nests that can house up to 500 birds and last for generations.

questions.question: Which ocean creature can produce light?
questions.explanation: The anglerfish produces light through bioluminescence in a rod-like appendage from its head to attract prey in the deep sea.

questions.question: Which mammal lays eggs?
questions.explanation: The platypus is one of only five monotreme mammals that lay eggs instead of giving birth to live young.

questions.question: Which animal has the largest eyes?
questions.explanation: The giant squid has the largest eyes of any animal, up to 10 inches (25 cm) in diameter - about the size of a dinner plate.

questions.question: Which animal has the most teeth?
questions.explanation: Garden snails have the most teeth of any animal - up to 25,000 tiny teeth on their radula, a tongue-like organ.
